explanation:
__linux__: preprocessor macro — if defined the entire sysctl-based body is omitted; determines which controlling expressions are present in compiled code (affects invariance analysis).
HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME: controls inclusion of sysctlbyname blocks; needed to know whether the if(0 >= ret) blocks that call sysctlbyname exist.
HAVE_SYSCTL, HAS_DECL_CTL_HW, HAS_DECL_HW_NCPUONLINE, HAS_DECL_HW_AVAILCPU: control inclusion of the sysctl() MIB-based branches; whether these conditional blocks and their controlling expressions are compiled.
sysctlbyname: declaration/semantics (return type, side-effects on the output buffer and on value_size) — the controlling expressions use its return value and the written-back ret/value_size; must know that it can change ret so the tests (0 >= ret) and (0 != sysctlbyname(...)) are not invariant.
sysctl: declaration/semantics — same reason as sysctlbyname for the MIB-based branches; its return value and effect on ret/value_size determine whether conditions can vary.
CTL_HW, HW_NCPUONLINE, HW_AVAILCPU: MIB constants used with sysctl() — affect which resource is queried and therefore whether sysctl() can succeed and change ret; needed to assess if the surrounding controlling expressions can become non-invariant.
size_t: typedef used for value_size and compared with sizeof(ret); semantics (width, unsignedness) matter for the expression (sizeof(ret) != value_size) which participates in controlling expressions.

These symbols are required to determine whether the controlling expressions in the function (e.g., if (0 >= ret), if ((0 != sysctlbyname(...)) || (sizeof(ret) != value_size)), and the conditional-compilation guards) can ever evaluate to different truth values at runtime or are compile-time/invariant for a given build configuration.
